content:
PathSegmentCollection Class

In this Article

Represents a collection of PathSegment objects that can be individually accessed by index.

Syntax

Declaration

[System.Windows.Localizability(System.Windows.LocalizationCategory.None, Readability=System.Windows.Readability.Unreadable)]
public sealed class PathSegmentCollection : System.Windows.Media.Animation.Animatable, System.Collections.Generic.ICollection<System.Windows.Media.PathSegment>, System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable<System.Windows.Media.PathSegment>, System.Collections.Generic.IList<System.Windows.Media.PathSegment>, System.Collections.IList

Inheritance Hierarchy

  • Object
  • DispatcherObject
  • DependencyObject
  • Freezable
  • System.Windows.Media.Animation.Animatable
  • PathSegmentCollection

Remarks

Except as noted, members of this class behave exactly as described by the IList<T>, ICollection<T>, and IEnumerable<T> documentation.

Freezable Features: Because it inherits from the Freezable class, the PathSegmentCollection class provides several special features: PathSegmentCollection objects can be declared as , shared among multiple objects, made read-only to improve performance, cloned, and made thread-safe. For more information about the different features provided by Freezable objects, see the Freezable Objects Overview.

XAML Implicit Collection Usage

<object>  
  <object.property>  
    oneOrMorePathSegmentObjectElements  
  </object.property>  
</object>

XAML Values

oneOrMorePathSegmentObjectElements
One or more PathSegment objects, declared using object element syntax.

Constructors summary

PathSegmentCollection()

Initializes a new instance of a PathSegmentCollection.
PathSegmentCollection(IEnumerable<PathSegment>)

Initializes a new instance of the PathSegmentCollection class with the specified collection of PathSegment objects.
PathSegmentCollection(Int32)

Initializes a new instance of the PathSegmentCollection class with the specified capacity, or the number of PathSegment objects the collection is initially capable of storing.

Properties summary

Count

Gets the number of path segments contained in the PathSegmentCollection.
Item(Int32)

Gets or sets the PathSegment at the specified zero-based index.

Methods summary

Add(PathSegment)

Adds a PathSegment to the end of the collection.
Clear()

Clears the collection of all segments and resets stem.Windows.Media.PathSegmentCollection.Count* to zero.
Clone()

Creates a modifiable clone of this PathSegmentCollection, making deep copies of this object's values. When copying dependency properties, this method copies resource references and data bindings (but they might no longer resolve) but not animations or their current values.
CloneCore(Freezable)
CloneCurrentValue()

Creates a modifiable clone of this PathSegmentCollection object, making deep copies of this object's current values. Resource references, data bindings, and animations are not copied, but their current values are.
CloneCurrentValueCore(Freezable)
Contains(PathSegment)

Returns a Boolean that indicates whether the specified PathSegment is contained within the collection.
CopyTo(PathSegment[],Int32)

Copies the entire PathSegmentCollection to a one-dimensional PathSegment array, starting at the specified index of the target array.
CreateInstanceCore()
FreezeCore(Boolean)
GetAsFrozenCore(Freezable)
GetCurrentValueAsFrozenCore(Freezable)
GetEnumerator()

Returns an enumerator that can iterate through the collection.
IndexOf(PathSegment)

Returns the index of the first occurrence of the specified PathSegment.
Insert(Int32,PathSegment)

Inserts a PathSegment into this PathSegmentCollection at the specified index.
Remove(PathSegment)

Removes the first occurrence of the specified PathSegment from this PathSegmentCollection.
RemoveAt(Int32)

Removes the PathSegment at the specified index from this PathSegmentCollection.

  • Item(Int32)

    Gets or sets the PathSegment at the specified zero-based index.

    public System.Windows.Media.PathSegment this[int index] { get; set; }

    Parameters

    • index
      Int32

      The zero-based index of the PathSegment object to get or set.

    Property Value

    • PathSegment

      The item at the specified index.

    Exceptions

    • ArgumentException

      value is null.

    • ArgumentOutOfRangeException

      index is not a valid index in the PathSegmentCollection.

    • NotSupportedException

      The PathSegmentCollection is read-only.

      - or -

      The PathSegmentCollection has a fixed size.

    Remarks

    Unlike typical implementations of Item, this implementation throws an ArgumentException if you attempt to insert a null (Nothing) reference.

Methods

  • Add(PathSegment)

    Adds a PathSegment to the end of the collection.

    public void Add (System.Windows.Media.PathSegment value);

    Parameters

    • value
      PathSegment

      The segment to add to the collection.

    Exceptions

    • ArgumentException

      value is null.

    • NotSupportedException

      The PathSegmentCollection is read-only.

      - or -

      The PathSegmentCollection has a fixed size.

    Remarks

    Because PathSegment objects derive from Freezable, they are copied when they are used. Therefore, you might not be able to later retrieve or remove the PathSegment you added to the collection using the original PathSegment object; the PathSegment in the collection is a copy of the original PathSegment and is considered a different PathSegment than the one you added.

    Unlike typical implementations of Add, this implementation throws an ArgumentException if you attempt to add a null (Nothing) reference.

    This method does not change the capacity of the PathSegmentCollection.

  • GetEnumerator()

    Returns an enumerator that can iterate through the collection.

    public System.Windows.Media.PathSegmentCollection.Enumerator GetEnumerator ();

    Returns

    • PathSegmentCollection+Enumerator

      An PathSegmentCollection+Enumerator that can iterate through the collection.

    Remarks

    Enumerators only allow reading the data in the collection. Enumerators cannot be used to modify the underlying collection.

    Initially, the enumerator is positioned before the first item in the collection. also brings the enumerator back to this position. At this position, calling Current throws an exception. Therefore, you must call MoveNext to advance the enumerator to the first item of the collection before reading the value of Current.

    Current returns the same object until either MoveNext or Reset is called. MoveNext sets Current to the next item.

    After the end of the collection is passed, the enumerator is positioned after the last item in the collection, and calling MoveNext returns false. If the last call to MoveNext returned false, calling Current throws an exception. To set Current to the first item of the collection again, you can call Reset followed by MoveNext.

    An enumerator remains valid as long as the collection remains unchanged. If changes are made to the collection, such as adding, modifying or deleting items, the enumerator is irrecoverably invalidated and the next call to MoveNext or Reset throws an InvalidOperationException. If the collection is modified between MoveNext and Current, Current will return the item that it is set to, even if the enumerator is already invalidated.

    The enumerator does not have exclusive access to the collection; therefore, enumerating through a collection is intrinsically not a thread-safe procedure. Even when a collection is synchronized, other threads could still modify the collection, which causes the enumerator to throw an exception. To guarantee thread safety during enumeration, you can either lock the collection during the entire enumeration or catch the exceptions resulting from changes made by other threads.
